Donelan''' (born 1949),<ref name="drawing">''Drawing on the Gay Experience: Cartoons from The Advocate'', by Gerard P. Donelan, "About the Cartoonist", 1987, Liberation Publications</ref> known primarily as just '''Donelan''', is an openly gay cartoonist. Part of the first wave<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcj.com/queers-and-comics-the-lgbtq-cartoonists-and-comics-conference/|title=Queers & Comics: The LGBTQ Cartoonists and Comics Conference {{!}} The Comics Journal|website=www.tcj.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> of LGBT cartoonists, he drew "It's a Gay Life", a regular single-panel cartoon feature in ''[[The Advocate]]'', for 15 years.<ref name="glbtq">[http://www.glbtq.com/arts/comic_strips_cartoons,3.html GBLTQ - arts - Comic Strips and Cartoons] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414144708/http://www.glbtq.com/arts/comic_strips_cartoons,3.html |date=April 14, 2009 }}</ref>
== Biography == [[File:Donelan-DrawingOnTheGayExperience.jpg|Cover of ''Drawing on the Gay Experience'' by Gerard P. Donelan|frame]] Donelan was born in [[Boston]], but grew up in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts]], the son of advertising artist Paul Donelan. He studied art at [[Southeastern Massachusetts Technological Institute]] but did not finish a degree, and went to work in retail.
In 1977, disappointed that [[Joe Johnson (cartoonist)|Joe Johnson]]'s pioneering gay comic strips ''Miss Thing'' and ''Big Dick'' had ended their run in ''The Advocate'', Donelan submitted a cartoon to the publication, which turned into a long-running series of his own. "It's a Gay Life" gently lampooned the gay "clone" culture of the time, focusing primarily on young and middle-aged gay men in their everyday lives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hoodedutilitarian.com/2011/11/gay-ghetto-comics-1-constructing-a-dominant-gay-habitus/|title=Gay Ghetto Comics 1: Constructing a Dominant Gay Habitus Â« The Hooded Utilitarian|website=www.hoodedutilitarian.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> He continued to work in retail while producing the series, which also yielded two paperback reprints: ''Drawing on the Gay Experience'' (1987) and ''Donelan's Back'' (1988).<ref name="drawing" />
For eight years Donelan also created sexually explicit comics in color for ''Advocate Men'', the magazine's erotica sister publication.<ref name=":0" /> His work has appeared in ''[[Frontiers (magazine)|Frontiers]]'', ''Gunner'', ''[[Gay Comix]]'' (including one front cover),<ref>[http://www.comics.org/issue/167520/ ''Gay Comix'' #7 at Grand Comics Database]</ref> and ''[[Meatmen (comics)|Meatmen]]'' (including two front covers and several back covers).<ref name="glbtq" />
In May 2015, he was a featured panelist at the first Queers & Comics conference, as one of the "Pioneers of Queer Men's Comics".<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=CLAGS: The Center for LGBTQ Studies|title=Queers & Comics: Pioneers of Queer Men's Comics|date=2016-09-08|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RThjuJvRR1Q|accessdate=2017-01-22}}</ref>
